As you know how to run code it’s time to learn how to comment it.

Comments are essential for making your code more understandable and for leaving notes to yourself or other developers. In JavaScript, there are two ways to add comments:

1. Single-Line Comments: Use // to add comments on a single line.
2. Multi-Line Comments: Enclose multi-line comments between /* and */

Why use comments?
  • Documentation: Comments provide information about the purpose and functionality of your code, making it easier for others (or yourself) to understand.
  • Debugging: Comments can be used to temporarily disable lines of code for debugging purposes without deleting them.
  • Explanation: Use comments to explain complex logic or algorithms in your code.

Best practices
  • Be Clear and Concise: Write comments that are easy to understand. Avoid unnecessary comments that simply restate the code.
  • Regularly Update Comments: Keep your comments up to date. If you change the code, make sure to update any relevant comments.
  • Avoid Over-Commenting: While comments are helpful, code should ideally be self-explanatory. Avoid overusing comments for simple and obvious code.
Now that you've grasped the basics of commenting, you'll find it beneficial for enhancing the readability and maintainability of your code.0/
